title: 103_hr929
content: Section 1 simplifies employment taxes on domestic services by increasing the threshold requirement from $50 to $300 in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code and the Social Security Act. Additionally, it coordinates the collection of domestic service employment taxes with the collection of income taxes. SEC. 3510 coordinates the collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. The general rule for domestic service employment taxes requires returns to be filed on a calendar year basis by the 15th day of the fourth month following the employer's taxable year. No deposits or installments are required for these taxes. Domestic service employment taxes are subject to estimated tax provisions under section 6654. For estimated tax purposes, domestic service employment taxes are treated as taxes imposed by chapter 2 for the employer's taxable year. Adjustments may be made in the application of estimated tax rules, and for the transitional rule in 1994, the tax amount is increased by 90 percent of the domestic service employment taxes. For estimated tax purposes, domestic service employment taxes are considered as taxes under chapter 2 for the employer's taxable year. The transitional rule in 1994 increases the tax amount by 90 percent of the domestic service employment taxes. The term 'domestic service in a private home of the employer' excludes certain services. Regulations may exempt employers liable for other employment taxes from this section. The Secretary will create necessary regulations for domestic service employment taxes. The Secretary has the authority to prescribe regulations for domestic service employment taxes and may enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for services in a private home. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home. Taxes collected will be treated as domestic service employment taxes and transferred to the state's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Amounts collected will be treated as taxes imposed by chapter 23 for purposes of subtitle F. The Secretary can enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on domestic service remuneration, which will be transferred to the state's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. Amounts collected will be treated as taxes imposed by chapter 23 for purposes of subtitle F. The amendments made by this section apply to remuneration paid in calendar years after 1993.
